awd_titl_txt: Conference: Research Analytics Summit: Building Capacity, Empowering Skill Transfer, and Energizing a Growing Community
awd_abstract_narration:
The GRANTED initiative highlights the need to encourage academic inquiry and knowledge creation from a wide variety of higher education institutions, especially emerging research institutions and minority-serving institutions (MSI’s). At Tribal Colleges and Universities (TCUs) in particular, there is a unique opportunity to support innovative epistemological and ontological frameworks that may offer important insights for dealing with issues like climate change, food security, and environmental change. With opportunities for different kinds of knowledge creation and problem-solving, it is critical to effectively support new models for what counts as basic and applied research. Using data to better understand, support, and identify unique characteristics of academic inquiry would be a unique and valuable outcome of the summit, which would be intentionally inclusive in welcoming diverse institutions into the research administration community. The potentially new ways of creating and apprehending knowledge through research at TCUs should not be seen as competing with traditional modes of academic inquiry. Rather, these frameworks can complement mainstream western science, offering a new lens for inquiry, discovery, and understanding.

The goal of this project is to host a national summit that focuses on key areas related to the use of data-informed decision-making within research administration, called Research Analytics. This will be the first of its kind conference dedicated to the field of research analytics and data-practitioners. Research Analytics is in its infancy at major research administration conferences. Many professionals working in this space have taken it on as only a small part of their position duties, and they are often not trained in data analysis or business intelligence systems. Outcomes of the meeting include a professional mentoring framework, professional collaboration, professional development, conference proceeding materials, and possibly identify future funding opportunities focused on research analytics. The summit will include participants from a variety of research intensive institutions including a focus on emerging research institutions, Tribal Colleges and Universities, and other minority-serving institutions. The summit will help build capacity through sharing of best practices, skill development, and building of networks. The meeting will focus on areas related to human capital and technology and skills. These themes will allow for interconnectivity of leadership, culture, governance, and technology—to provide informed and strategic decision-making within the research enterprise.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF KENTUCKY RESEARCH FOUNDATION, THE

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The 2024 Research Analytics Summit, held on March 11-12 in Albuquerque, New Mexico, convened experts and professionals to explore advancements in research analytics within the field of research administration. Funded by the National Science Foundation's GRANTED program (award no. 2324388), the summit featured a series of 37 presentations and discussions that underscored the pivotal role data analytics has in research administration. More than 195 individuals from across the U.S., Canada, the United Kingdom, and United Arab Emirates attended the summit.

The summit brought together leading experts, innovators, and stakeholders from across academia, industry, and government to explore the transformative role of data analytics in driving research excellence within the field of research administration. Held under the theme "Building Capacity, Empowering Skill Transfer, and Energizing a Growing Community" the summit served as a platform for exchanging insights, showcasing advancements in new methods and technology, and fostering collaborations to help build capacity for an emerging field and community within research administration.

The summit focused on fostering promising practices in two critical areas:

  1. Human Capital: Which includes a focus on leadership commitment to support a strategy around success in analytics, and value of data-informed strategies. A culture of practices across the institution where data contributes to decision-making and a focus on clear governance in policies, practices, and standards for data collection, access, and use.
  2. Technology and Skills: Advanced and coherent IT infrastructure to store, manage, and analyze information with robust integrations. Skilled staffing, techniques, and resources. Data access and quality, tools to use data to drive decision-making across the institution.

The summit reaffirmed the critical role of data and analytics in advancing societal progress and transformation within emerging research institutions. Research Analytics is an emerging field within all types of higher education institutions. Emerging research institutions and less-resourced institutions can utilize research analytics to build capacity, build strategy, and grow their research enterprise. The outcomes of the summit provide a clear roadmap for leveraging these tools to achieve greater innovation, inclusivity, and impact across all research domains.

Key outcomes from the summit include:

Innovative Analytical Approaches:

  • Where Do I Start? by Andrea Crystelle and Lori Schultz provided foundational strategies for integrating analytics into research workflows.
  • You are What You Eat ... and Enter into Data Fields by Hansa Magee and Nick Bilyk emphasized the importance of data integrity in research outcomes.
  • Representing Your Institution Through Data by Lou Hurst discussed methods for effectively showcasing institutional research strengths through data.

Ethical Data Use and Governance:

  • Exploring Research Metadata Governance with Design Thinking
    •
  • by Scott Woods and Natalie Simonson addressed the challenges of managing research metadata responsibly.
  • Data Governance and Stewardship 101
    •
  • by Lori Ann M. Schultz provided a comprehensive overview of establishing robust data governance frameworks.

Artificial Intelligence in Research Analytics:

  • Bringing Artificial Intelligence to Research Analytics: Research Highlighter-MatchMaker at SUNY UAlbany by Tianning Huang and Yuemin Li showcased AI applications in enhancing research collaborations.
  • Generating Impact Narratives with AI by Sean Newell and Charity Elifritz demonstrated how AI can be utilized to articulate research impact effectively.

Capacity Building and Education:

  • Introduction to Research Administration Dashboards using Tableau by Alex Wagner offered practical guidance on developing interactive dashboards for research management.
  • Introduction to Descriptive Research Administration Statistics using Excel by Alex Wagner provided essential skills for analyzing research data using common tools.
    •

Collaborative Initiatives:

  • RAMP Research Analytics Mentorship Program by Andrea Christelle, Lou Hurst, and Baron Wolf introduced a mentorship framework aimed at fostering expertise in research analytics.
  • Bridging the Gap for Research Analytics: Fostering Collaboration between Research Administration, Institutional Research, Enterprise IT, and Research Computing in Higher Education by Ashley Stauffer and Paulina Krys highlighted strategies for cross-departmental collaboration to enhance research analytics capabilities.

Future Directions: The summit successfully fostered a collaborative atmosphere, enabling attendees to exchange ideas and establish networks that transcend disciplinary and institutional boundaries. Attendees left equipped with actionable strategies, ethical guidelines, and a renewed commitment to integrating advanced analytics into their research administration practices. The discussions and initiatives unveiled during the summit underscore the potential of analytics to shape the future of research, making it more impactful, inclusive, and data-driven.

By addressing topics ranging from governance and AI to capacity building and institutional representation, the 2024 Research Analytics Summit provided a comprehensive roadmap for leveraging analytics to drive transformative change in research and innovation.


Last Modified: 01/18/2025
Modified by: Baron G Wolf
